That's their business plan and for them to figure out. If you know your market and have done your research, as long as you get paid at the level you want, then you have won the sale. I make a lot of money purchasing items that Sellers have not done their research and just list it for a garage sale price to get rid of it, when a small inquiry into the going rate could have grossed them 25% more profit.

There isn't anything wrong with it. It's how a lot of us on here make our money. We buy something at a low prices, compared to what the item is worth, and then sell it at a higher price to make a profit. Where the item is sold is pretty irrelevant.
I exclusively sell my items on eBay because there is a larger base of customers. But, I buy most of my items on Craigslist and Letgo; that doesn't mean though if I see something on Amazon or Craigslist I won't buy it and resell it on eBay.

That's the whole point of the shotgun clause. Any of the shareholders owning stock attributed to the buy-sell agreement, which has the shotgun clause within it, has the right to invoke it; it's just a type of exit clause.
It's going to come down to how and what effects result from the triggering shareholders perspective. Remember these types of issues are rules by the language of the contract.

I found it annoying at first because I had shit going on as well, but towards the end I found it amusing, almost like a subconscious game we were playing with the class.

Valid points. I'm in a similar boat rank wise. I started Law School not knowing what to expect and piled way to much on my plate. From my second term on I held a A-/B+ average, but still closed out the degree slightly under a 3.0 because my first two terms were horrendous. Realistically, I'm one of those individuals who has both sets of skills and that's why going solo always peaked my interest. I didn't get in this game to drown under someone else's paperwork. I'm actually learning a lot about myself in this time of transition and it has helped me understand my true goals. I'm a hustler by nature and always buying/selling things. My true passion is real estate; I'd like to eventually invest once I'm financially stable to do so.

Appreciate this.
There are a lot of job opportunities in my regional area with the title "Attorney" and I know once the license comes it won't be as hard to find a full-time position. My goal is to alleviate some of the stresses my Wife has encountered while I went to law school. We understood it was an unconventional investment and was going to take time to produce. The goal is to make $45k+ which will allow her to quit one part-time job and focus solely one her other one. I'm just frustrated with the current status of my life and the fact I'm being severely underpaid. I was given the opportunity to work over time and have put in 60 hours each week since then, even then I'm still underpaid in my opinion ($15/hr base; $22.50 OT 1.5x).
I have been networking with the Attorneys I work with and they have introduced me to a few others who have came to the office. I will continue to build a network and create possible opportunities as time moves forward. I know it will be easier once a few other variables fall into place...the rest will work itself out.
Thanks again.

Edit: Everything I've worked for is contingent upon a license I may or may not receive. I don't know what to do if I don't get licensed. If I do get licensed, I know what I am going to do. I'm in a phase right now of uncertainty and it is wreaking havoc on my life.

I appreciate the candor. I think that's the crux of my issue, I don't know what to do because I haven't been doing it...so how do I know what is what without trying things.
It's not that my heart isn't in crim defense, I just have never done it and always shut it out of my head...until now. I just want to work, make money, and pay my bills; I don't care what I do. I see what your saying, I have always done things in a semi-linear pattern so my experiences/education have lined up so that's how my brain thinks long term. You just helped me decide, thanks.

That's what I'm severally torn on. I did not take steps in law school to be on Moot Court or Law review and don't have a strong drive to practice criminal defense...even though that's what by background is in. I am more interested in business, real estate, and other transnational work--but criminal law is something that has always come to me and it's something I know intrinsically. I feel as though I could leverage my background to get the job at the firm, even thought I don't have a strong interest in practicing criminal defense. All my friends are law enforcement at local and state levels and I forged that route to venture off to law school because of something in my past I couldn't personally live with (part of the long story). I just don't want to walk out of this document review gig not having an idea of what my next position is going to be with a mortgage and my student loans due.

I'm not barred to practice law in my given state, again, that's part of the long story. I'm still in the licensing process and should know in a month or so.
However, I've done the research in anticipation. I live in a location on the cusp of rural/metropolitan area where it would be easy to serve both types of clients. I have major highways in and around me which would make it easy to get where I need to go. The legal market where I live is very under saturated; relatively un-touched I'd say. The county I live in barely has a functioning bar association, I thought about stepping in and helping run it once I do get barred.
The counties around me are over-saturated in my opinion; one of them is in a way the mecca of the state and there is an overwhelming number of attorneys focused there. I don't have the exact numbers, but its something like 10,000 vs. 1,000, the latter being my location; it's something insane.
I work in a law firm right now doing document review for them and have networked pretty hard with all of the attorneys in the office. I'm confident once this review is done, I can go to them to find my next position. My confidence is founded on one of the younger associates telling my flat out to ask the president and other partners if they know of anything; it's a smaller firm focused on a niche area, but push out big numbers. I've been working my ass for them to show them I'm no chump and I mean business, they've gotten the hint I am business first, but I'm also someone who can hold an intelligent conversation.
I have some savings, but I was holding off on spending it on going solo immediately upon licensing. I have a substantial amount of student loans and would much rather find "somewhere" to work to develop the solo on the side before jumping with both feet. I have a relatively small amount of bills (house, student loans, insurance, monthly expenses) each month. With my wife's two jobs, I need a job that pays $45,000 or more, anything over that mark would be a plus. We have been living off her salary for the past year or so and have been living decent and still have managed to save. At the $45k mark we would still live of her income and any remaining would be dumped on my student loan along with my entire salary; we plan to aggressively pay down the loan.
I studied a wide range of subjects while in law school and I'm naturally intrigued by anything that floats in front of my face. Realistically I would be comfortable doing transnational work. I have some Bankruptcy experience as well.
I have not reached out to anyone in the area I plan on practicing because I'm not at that point yet. I know of a few places that would more than likely allow me to work in their location, including the firm I'm working at now. I was going to cross that bridge when it came.

Individually speaking, I've graduated form law school and have passed the Bar Exam in Michigan; I'm currently in the licensing process to practice law. I specialized my degree in business transactions and real estate law. That being said, I would seek the advice of an attorney anytime you encounter a scenario where you yourself individually are going to be taking on financial risks, where there is language regarding how ownership is divided, or where there is no paperwork at all.
I'm a firm believer of the fact that in the contracting world many of the problems that arise come about due to poor contract execution or none at all. Many of the problems in business can be ironed out before hand. For example, if you have a Partnership, but there is no Partnership Agreement. Or further, if you have a L.L.C, but there is no Operating Agreement. These documents are essential to how the given business is ran. However, even if your have these documents in place they still may be written in a way that touches all the bases, but essentially does nothing for you specifically. Websites like Legal Zoom, while they serve a purpose and are successful, their documents are not specifically tailored for each individual client; there what you call a boilerplate document which is the bare minimal of what the law requires. When ever your in a negotiating stance you want to put your best foot forward and get in a position that best suits you.
In relation to the structure, you hit the nail on the head. How is the business going to be structures, i.e. what type of entity is going to be used. There are many types of business (partnerships, LLC, Member Managed/Manager Managed LLC, S vs. C Corporation, Non-Profit) and how you choose will depend on the type of business your getting into. There is no right way to choose, but you want to choose right because the wrong choice can make you personally liable for your cohorts screw-ups.

I completely agree with this comment. It's pretty clique, but individuals in those scenarios have learned skills to keep themselves alive. They have perfected and found their skills over a long and hard road through life. But, I also agree with running a criminal record check. It's one thing to have a DUI vs. Assault/Child Abuse...you just want to make sure your not jumping into business with a hothead.

WRITING.TITLE: Recent Graduate Seeking Career Advice
WRITING.TEXT:
It's a long story, but I am re-thinking the type of law I want to practice.
I don't have any particular experience in Criminal Law, however, I have a Bachelors Degree in Criminal Justice, Counter-Terrorism Certificate, and over five years of experience doing private security in conjunction with the local police department. I went to law school based on the long story, it's not something I regret entirely, just a few choices would have been more beneficial.
Regardless, I specialized my studies in Business Transactions and Real Estate. I'm having trouble finding a "law job" post graduation and I'm tired of doing the document review thing.
There is a criminal defense firm hiring a part-time law clerk on craigslist...and I am truly torn on sending my credentials.
Any thoughts? Much appreciated.

What does the paperwork say? Do you understand what your getting into contractually? Is this something you should consult an expert on? How is the start-up structured? Does the start-up have any existing debts you would stand to incur? Is there set goals and plans to achieve those goals? Is this something that your comfortable taking on the risk associated with the endeavor? How will you, and or, will you get paid?
...I could probably continue for an hour...
You can never be to sure of something without asking the proper questions.
Same thought!
Cool! Glad I could help.

I think your over-thinking the question maybe, do you have facts we can see?

I can second this, heavily. The Bar is an exam to test your capabilities, it will not ease up on you. You have to be disciplined and deliberate in your studies. Themis will not hold your hand and you have to be proactive, have a place, and execute that plan. I can attest to the exact same thing--had friends take Themis and skated through thinking just because they got more % done they were good; they were wrong.

Yea, that is another reason why I was turned off by Barbri. I had a buddy who took the Bar at the same time and did Barbri, he passed, but also supplemented their writing portion with a state specific writing course through a 3rd party.
I did Themis' schedule for the majority of my studies, then with about 1.5 months to go I started to review and practice on the Flex study to tailor it more specific to my needs. I completed 67.6% of Themis' course and passed will a 10+ point spread in points; I was a B to B+ student in law school.

I did Themis and thought it was a good course, passed the first time.
The course allowed you to change course if you did not feel you needed to cover something. For example, the term before I graduated I took a Sales course covering negotiable instruments and Article II of the UCC. While I was going through the Themis course it called for lectures tailored to those subject, seeing I just took them, I skipped those lectures and was able to apply my time towards something more beneficial.
My point: Barbri is more ridgid in their course flow, where Themis is more relaxed.

Yes, with any collectible you have a peaks and valleys.
The generation that played N64 is at the prime nostalgia age, thus they want to escape back to their youth. As time goes on that base will collect what games/materials they need for their setup. As time passes there will be less of a demand for the products, in turn, prices will have to become more competitive for a smaller market.
When the competition is not at a peak, the more collectible/rare items will hold their value; while the more common games will be low.
I would say the accessories will hold their value more; everyone is going to need parts for their controllers or new ones all together.

This.
I would say start with your Letgo/Craigslist search to find local people selling stuff. You local market is going to be the most potential for cheaper stuff. You can easily find a system and a controller for $40-50 to set you up. It's going to be the games that your going to have to search for diligently for the best price.
I got back into the N64 game two weeks ago and it was a surprise to see how much this stuff runs; and I yelled at my parents for selling all my childhood gear at a garage sale (smh).
If you can find games locally, great. If not, your going to want to go on Ebay and just vulture games at a price your comfortable paying. Today I bought Super Smash Bros for $39.99 w/ $4.00 shipping. I would say from watching for the past few weeks that $44.99 is a decent deal; I've seen them sell upwards of $60.00, so it just depends on your comfort level and value of the game.
This Reddit Sub is excellent and has a TON of information. I must admit I've spent A LOT of time on here in the past two weeks getting my setup going.
EDIT: There is also a big difference in "Collecting" verses "Reminiscing." If your looking to just step back in time your going to spend a lot less money; if your collecting, your not going to get out cheap any way you look at it.

Exactly. You'll get hooked. I use the app at garage sales all the time. Once you practice finding your items it's really simple to use/list.
(1) I search for item based off trigger words (name, manuf., etc.)
(2) I see how many current items are listed. I look for exact same item or similar items, it's going to depend on what you have.
(3) Then I hit refine and look up sold/completed listings to see what has sold most recently. That way you can judge how fast that item moves and the variance in price. Then you can go back to the current listings to judge what price you can pay/sell for based on what's available and to compete with the current listings.
(4) Once you've bought the item redo the search and find your item. There will be a "Sell Similar Item" button you can click on. This literally will copy and late the entire listing you looked up except the description, shipping, and price. Once your in the template you just go through each part and put in your desired information. Then you list it.
I can literally do this in 5-10 mins depending on the item. I can find an exact same item it's a lot easier. I hardly ever create my listings from scratch anymore.

I can list something in 2-3 mins. Where a laptop takes a bit longer to upload photos, write in data, etc.
I've bought items at garage sales, listed then in my car, and by the time I'm at another sale--they've sold.
It's just very user friendly.
I typically know my shipping costs or offer free shipping in the items I sell so I don't fuss with the shipping charges; I deal mostly in smalls.

Hat do you want to get out of the gym? Seriously. What will you use when you go there? I did this thing with LA for three years, then realized I had everything at my house.
Everywhere you go there is a floor: Push-ups, sit-ups, lunges, etc.
Sidewalk: Running, walking, jogging, etc.
Most of what I did was doable at home.
The only benefit from it was being able to play basketball and using their water to shower. But over time the gas I used to get to the gym 3-4 times a week would have covered my own water at home.
If it's being around people who have similar mindsets, that's commendable, and sometimes a good reason.
My point is everyone doesn't need a gym Membership and if you want to save $30 a week and that $100 start up cost...try out the home gym you're already a member of.
Agreed. Maybe it's an update of some sort.
Incredible how it can go from a record drought to over saturated. How are y'all gonna catch this water to save and use in future droughts?

It's not that simple. They signed a contract with their lender that has an acceleration clause in it, which states that any unauthorized transfer of the property would give the lender the right to call the entire loan due.
If you really want to do this correctly, you should consult a real estate attorney in your jurisdiction. Find an attorney who will give you a *free* consultation and just lay out what y'all wanna do.
By drafting your own deeds and doing it hokey, your going to create issues in the chain of title which could lead to thousands to clean it up.
Ask your Attorney what:
1) Assumption vs Subject to means 2) Novation from original Promissory Note means
